00020 // Connection directions. These of course are with respect to the location of the dom0 containing
00021 // this connection table. Each connection will have an associated entry in the remote server table, but
00022 // with the opposite direction.
00023 typedef enum connection_type {
00024     UNUSED = 0,
00025     INCOMING,   // servicing a remote guest domain
00026     OUTGOING    // offloading work to a remote machine
00027 } conn_type_t;
00028 
00029 typedef int             socket_t;  // just to make the code more legible
00030 //typedef pthread_mutex_t ctlock_t;  // lock for entire connection table
00031 
00057 typedef struct connection
00058 {
00059     int                 valid;      // true if this structure is associated with a live connection
00060     pthread_t           tid;        // associated thread ID, remote or local
00061 
00062     struct sockaddr_in  *address;
00063     socklen_t           address_len;
00064     int                 address_family;
00065 
00066     socket_t            socket;     // socket to connect to on this machine for remote communcation
00067     int                 socktype, protocol;   // and its type/protocol
00068 
00069     conn_type_t         type;
00070     strm_t              strm;
00071     //network_state_t     state;      // TODO (implement this) state this connection is in
00072 
00073     // TODO Instead of statically allocating these, create pointers. During connection
00074     // reservation/unreservation they can become allocated and deallocated for use.
00075  //   char request_data_buffer[TOTAL_XFER_MAX];
00076  //   char response_data_buffer[TOTAL_XFER_MAX];
00077 
00078     // the pointers held the  dynamically allocated memory required by the
00079     // extra buffer for requests or responses, respectively
00080     // @todo they should eventually should substitute the request_data_buffer
00081     // and response_data_buffer
00082     // you are responsible for allocating and releasing the request
00083     // and response buffers.
00084     char * pReqBuffer;
00085     char * pRspBuffer;
00086 
00087     // sizes of the request and response buffers, respectively

00091     cudaError_t lastCudaErrorRemote;

00155 /*
00156  *  Put (send) data.
00157  *  @todo Put and Send should probably accept remote packets, not all this fine-grained detail. Maybe
00158  *  call it put_strm.
00159  *
00160  * @param conn (out) where the data will be put
00161  * @param msg (in) what data will be put to conn
00162  * @param int (in) what is the size of the data to be put
00163  * @todo strange return values
00164  * @return -EINVAL
00165  *         0 if sent finished
00166  *         1 normal exit from the function
00167  */
00168 int put( conn_t *conn, void *msg, int len );
